_exec_summary.SummaryText:
*-United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 68, Subpart E, Emergency Response

*-American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping

*-California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials


ES-4.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.


ES-5.0 THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated on July 30, 2020 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.


ES-6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the aqua ammonia process at the Facility will be implemented as needed.


ES-7.0 THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Aqua Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of a storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 190,000 pounds of aqua ammonia. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and D stability modelling parameters.

Risk Management Plan
Pleasant Grove Retail, Grow West
Pleasant Grove, California


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR 2745.3)


ES-1.0 FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Pleasant Grove Retail, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Pleasant Grove or the Pleasant Grove Facility) at 4036 Pleasant Grove Road, Pleasant Grove, California 95668 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.


ES-2.0 FACILITY INFORMATION

The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers).

*-Aqua ammonia (NH4OH) is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients. 

*-Aqua ammonia (24.3%)  is received by truck and stored in two, 25,000-gallon storage tanks at the site. 

  Tank 1: 25,000 gals of liquid; 190,000 lbs of aqua; 46,250 lbs equivalent pounds of NH3
  Tank 2: 25,000 gals of liquid; 190,000 lbs of aqua; 46,250 lbs equivalent pounds of NH3

TOTAL: 50,000 gals; 380,000 lbs of aqua; 92,500 lbs equivalent.

The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 380,000 pounds. 


ES-3.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

SAFETY INFORMATION:  Pleasant Grove Retail ensures that information concerning covered process and regulated substances are up-to-date a

nd available for review by employees. The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered process took place on August 27, 2020.

HAZARD REVIEW:  A hazard review of the ammonia process is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the process. The most recent update of the hazard review for the aqua ammonia process handling and storage was conducted on July 30, 2020. Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.

OPERATING PROCEDURES:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered process and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures were last revised on August 27, 2020. 

TRAINING:  The Pleasant Grove Facility staff, as well as Grow West corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program was last reviewed on October 6, 2019. The current training program is comprised of the following:
  1. Initial employee training.
  2. Periodic refresher training.
  3. Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.
  4. Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training.
  5. Training records for each employee.

MAINTENANCE:  The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventive maintenance, recordkeeping, and training. The latest equipment inspections were conducted in May 2020 and the latest review of maintenance procedures was conducted on August 27, 2020.

RMP CHANGE MANAGEMENT:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues

must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Aqua Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility RMP Change Management (RMPCM) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures. The procedures were last reviewed verified on August 26, 2020.

PRE START-UP REVIEW: The pre-startup review (PSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Aqua Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected process are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre-startup review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the RMPCM review. Additionally, a pre-startup review is performed in conjunction with the RMPCM review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures. The PSR procedures were last reviewed or verified on August 26, 2020.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted on June 25, 2019.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

OTHER CODE APPLICABILITY:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):

*-United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans
